block.p: I GREW up in Marshall, Minn. My grandparents all spoke Norwegian. We spoke English at home but we would say ''takk for maten,'' which means thank you for the food.

I GREW up in Marshall, Minn. My grandparents all spoke Norwegian. We spoke English at home but we would say ''takk for maten,'' which means thank you for the food.
I vividly remember a sleepover at someone's house. I said ''takk for maten'' after dinner and no one understood a word I said. I didn't realize they weren't English words.

My father was a Lutheran minister and knew people from all walks of life. When I was about 7, a tornado hit the town of Tracy. You could see the tornado from our town. And there were people who were wounded and killed as a result. At any moment your plans could be interrupted.

I was a good student, but what I really liked to do was organize a group of people to do something. When I was 16, I was elected president of the Southwestern Minnesota District Luther League and later was the youngest member of the Commission for a New Lutheran Church.

At college one of my professors recommended me for a Rhodes scholarship. The interviews were at the Minneapolis Club, a private business club. I had never been to a club like that. I was wearing a blue suit my grandmother had helped me pick out. There was a wine-and-cheese reception, and many of the students knew each other from high school and were now in the Ivy League. I felt kind of out of place.

One question at the interview was what I wanted to be professionally. I said I wanted to be a college professor. After I received the scholarship one of the interviewers said to me: ''I want you to know none of us think you'll be a college professor. We think you'll be head of an organization.''

I was at Oxford for four years. I studied at Trinity College and then I was affiliated with the Centre for Socio-Legal Studies. While there, I worked on a two-part article about the impact of medical malpractice that was published in the British Medical Journal in June 1987. I was the lead author. After publication I got a couple of bottles of Champagne, and we were sitting around celebrating. One of the other authors started considering the next set of articles. I was much more interested in fixing the problem.
When I returned to the United States I got a job as director of research at Partners National Health Plans in Minnesota and joined United HealthCare two years later.

I was expecting my first child in late August 1989. He was born on a Sunday at 5 p.m. The next morning I called my assistant at 9 a.m. and she said, ''The governor's office has called three times already this morning.''

I called the governor's office and his chief of staff, Lynn Anderson, said, ''The governor would like to meet with you this afternoon.'' I said any other day I could rearrange my schedule but I just had a baby.
The governor, Rudy Perpich, was setting up the Minnesota Health Care Access Commission to look for ways to develop a state universal health plan within a budget.

The Minnesota State Fair was going on at the time. Five days later I fed the baby and then a friend dropped me off at the fairgrounds, which were two miles from my house. I met the governor, who asked me to be chairman of the commission and then announced its creation. Then the same friend picked me up at the fair gates. I went home to feed the baby.
During the course of the commission's work I found out I was expecting twins. I ended up on two months of bed rest. The legislature didn't fully finance the health care plan we proposed.
In January 1993 I got a call from an assistant in the White House policy office asking me to serve on the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform. The boys were 1 1/2 and 3 1/2.

My husband and I talked about the challenges of a commute. The idea was that I'd come home every third weekend, but I ended up coming home two out of four weekends. I commuted for six months and lived with friends. My husband, parents, mother-in-law and a baby sitter watched the boys. About a week and a half after I arrived home, they got the chickenpox.
I cook breakfast instead of dinner. It can be blueberry pancakes and eggs or bacon and grits. It's recognizing the things that are most important. I learned that, having three kids.
LOIS QUAM President of public and senior markets groups, United HealthCare
BIRTH DATE June 12, 1961
PASTIME Enjoys visiting greenmarkets and cooking for family and friends.
OFFICE SPACE: THE BOSS
